title: How to tell if a scientific paper is correct - Quora

response.answer_text: Being published in a peer-reviewed journal (preferably with a high impact factor) is a start. Not a guarantee - but it’s certainly better than being announced by press conference or published outside the peer reviewed journalsBeing cited by a lot of other papers - preferably written by respected scientists - helps. Although, any paper that seems to break new ground will be highly cited unless it’s shown to be wrongMaking testable predictions - especially if tested and found to be correct - helps even more.Lasting for years or decades is nice (although not essential)And, of course, your own BS sense. Does it make sense to you, or does it seem as though the authors are really stretching their data and its interpretation? If your own BS sensor goes off…you need to convince yourself that the paper is likely to be right.Something else to remember is that it’s hard to say that a paper is “correct” or “incorrect.” The paper that first introduced the concept of an asteroid strike wiping out the dinosaurs had some mistakes in it - but the overall concept seems to be pretty accurate.

Roger Bacon invented the modern scientific paper. This invention is based on the power of an experiment to validate a concept. A most important part of the scientific paper is the EXPERIMENTAL section. Roger Bacon prescribed that anyone who could successfully replicate the experiment, and obtain the results that were reported, would be convinces of the validity of the phenomena and the interpretations of the original author. In other words, if you can duplicate the experiments, you will be convinced that the paper is correct. In labs where I worked, we frequently duplicated experiments reported. Not every lab has the ability to do this. We have to rely on the record of the authors to report things professionally. Occasionally we have to call up the author and get additional instructions on how to conduct the experiments. I pity the specialties that must rely on what someone says. People frequently lie, or make up things in their heads and pass them off as true.

First question - is it published in a peer-reviewed journal? The peers who support the journal’s editors will generally know much more than you do about the subject in general, correct use of the relevant methodologies, and proper interpretation of experimental results. Many “scientific results” are published in non-reviewed journals. Scientific results move the field forward only when they meet standards of reproducibility, and non-reviewed journals regularly publish papers that do not meet that standard. Otherwise, you might ask scientists you know WHO HAVE PROFESSIONAL EXPERTISE IN THAT PARTICULAR SUBJECT MATTER whether they have studied the paper and what they think of it. Finally, you might educate yourself to a level of experience that allows you to critique the paper yourself or, ultimately, try to reproduce the results yourself. Simply assessing that the paper “feels right” or ”makes sense” in no way validates the results.

Wait. As Arthur C. Clarke once said (paraphrasing from memory), “Scientists can usually get to the bottom of things in 50 years, if there’s any bottom to be gotten to.” (*) Admittedly, not everyone has 50 years for professional researchers to replicate findings, build on them, test contradictory ideas, and so on. So in the short term, this might help.  From A Rough Guide to Spotting Bad Science * Edit: Found the original quote! “In orthodox science, it’s very rare for a controversy to last more than, a generation; 50 years at the outside. Yet this is exactly what’s happened with the paranormal, which is the best possible proof that most of it is rubbish. It never takes that long to establish the facts – when there are some facts.” — Arthur C. Clarke, 10 July 1985, “Strange Powers: The Verdict,” Arthur C. Clarke’s World of Strange Powers

See if other papers cite it and if when they cite it confirm its results. “Repeatability” of results is at the core of the scientific process. Of course, if you are an expert, it is possible that you will identify errors missed by the review process, but we assume that since you ask the question, you are clueless about what you read. So, multiple positive citations is a good indication of a correct paper.
You can tell be acceptance for the publication by the blind-refereed journal.
